g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
can come together, build trust, impro
ve understanding, and ultimately converge in their objectives
Development pathways evolve as the result of the countless decisions and actions at all levels of societal
structure, as well due to the emergent dynamics within and
technological systems, and the biogeophysical environment. Society can choose to make decisions and
take actions with the shared intention of influencing the future development pathway toward specific
The SDGs provide a lens on diverse national and local development objectives. Humankind currently
faces multiple sustainability challenges that together present global society with the challenge of
assessing, deliberating, and attempting to bring
about a viable, positive future development pathway.
Ecological sustainability challenges include reducing GHG emissions, protecting the ozone, controlling
pollutants such as aerosols and persistent organics, managing nitrogen and phosphorous cycles, etc.
, which are necessary to address the rising risks to biodiversity and ecosystem
conflict, persistent poverty and deprivation, various forms of pervasive and systemic discrimination and
socially corrosive inequality. The global adoption of the SDGs and their underlying
reflect a negotiated prioritisation of these common challenges.
the process of shifting development pathways. The lines illustrate different
pment pathways through time, some of which (shown here toward the top of the figure)
obstacles to the adoption and effective implementation of sustainable development policies,
access to a rich policy toolbox for accelerating mitigatio
pathways (shown here toward the bottom of the figure)
obstacles to adopting and effectively implementing sustainable development policies
A richer tool box enables faster,
hways branch and branch again, signifying how a diversity of decision
(policy makers, organizations, investors, voters, consumers, etc.) are continuously
influence which of many potential development pathways society follows. Som
clearly within the domain of mitigation policy. For example, what level carbon price, if any, should be
imposed? Should fossil fuel subsidies be removed?
Most decisions, of course, fall outside the direct
realm of choices beyond mitigation policy
, and requires identifying those choices that are
important determinants of the existing obstacles
Addressing these choices coherently shifts the development pathway away from a continuation of
